title: When a neutral atom contains two protons and gains three electrons, what charge does it require? - Quora

response.answer_text: The question is strangely phrased. An atom containing two protons must be some isotope of helium, so it is either helium-3 or helium-4 if it is stable. A neutral atom of helium contains two electrons. If it then gained three electrons it would then be a triply negatively charged ion of helium: [math]\text{He} (-3).[/math] But I don’t think such an ionic state can exist for any length of time. Perhaps what you mean is that the bare nucleus of helium gains three electrons: in that case it will not be neutral. It will have charge -1, and be a negative helium ion. This ion can be made, without too much difficulty, and it’s done all the time in particle accelerators.

If the neutral atom did exactly as you specify, it would become negatively charged by one charge (+2-3 = -1) However, it's a pretty strange question. Even though I work on the ITER project, I don't think it's likely that you would normally manage to get a neutral atom to gain two protons. In everyday life, atoms stay forever with the same number of protons they were born with. Certainly, under the rules of Daltonian chemistry.
